author: By An-My Lê
title: A Photographer’s American Road Trip
description: An-My Lê has been surveying our country over the past four years, finding power in unexpected places.
content: These past four years, I’ve been on a photographic road trip of the United States. It often seems that there are two Americas, left and right, looking at the same place from radically different and irreconcilable perspectives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Far-Right Groups Are Behind Most U.S. Terrorist Attacks, Report Finds
description: White supremacist groups have carried out a majority of “terrorist plots and attacks” this year, according to a report by a think tank, the Center for Strategic and International Studies.
content: White supremacists and other like-minded groups have committed a majority of the terrorist attacks in the United States this year, according to a report by a security think tank that echoed warnings made by the Department of Homeland Security this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Matthew Sedacca
title: Relieved to Be Back at the Gym, but Is It Safe?
description: City gyms were allowed to reopen on Sept. 2, but lingering concerns about indoor workouts mean many may not endure.
content: The coronavirus has made a routine trip to the gym feel like a health threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Trump’s Claims About Hunter Biden Send Online Activity Soaring
description: Google searches and Facebook posts about Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son rose after President Trump’s misleading comments at Thursday’s debate.
content: In Thursday’s presidential debate, President Trump made several misleading claims about the business dealings of the family of his opponent, Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Turning 100, a Former Spanish Soldier Laments the Curse of His Birth Year
description: Andreu Canet is one of the last survivors of the “baby bottle conscription.” Born in 1920, they were drafted as teenagers in an ill-fated bid to stop Franco from winning Spain’s civil war.
content: CARDEDEU, Spain — Andreu Canet turns 100 next month. And his birth year, as it turned out, was a curse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Emmett Lindner
title: Bangkok Is Engulfed by Protests. What’s Driving Them?
description: Rebellious youths. A history of coups. A royal family protected by laws that can punish critics. All are key ingredients in the struggle convulsing Thailand.
content: BANGKOK — Protests in Thailand that began as a student-led revolt against the military’s influence on the classroom have ballooned to encompass a sweeping range of issues at the heart of the country’s deep-rooted social and economic disparities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Beautiful Day for a List: How We Chose 50 Examples of PBS’s Impact
description: We asked nearly two dozen writers for nominations. Many of their odes to classic comedies and iconic documentaries were personal. That was exactly the point.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: How a Journeyman Infielder Taught Dave Roberts to Slow the Game Down
description: When Roberts was an information-hungry 26-year-old in the minor leagues, he soaked up valuable advice from a veteran third baseman named Jeff Manto that still serves him.
content: When the Dodgers won the National League pennant last week, Dave Roberts, the Los Angeles manager, was unusually emotional as he spoke at a lectern about how this would prove to be the Dodgers’ year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Last Temptation of NeverTrump
description: A voice in my head makes the case to re-elect the president.
content: Last Sunday this section was turned over to essays making the case against the re-election of Donald Trump. I read all of the pieces, and found more than a few points with which I disagreed. But my commitment to contrarianism only goes so far: Fundamentally I agree with my colleagues that Trump should not be …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: World Series: Dodgers Top the Rays in Game 3 With a Stellar Pitching Performance
description: Walker Buehler delivered an outstanding performance on the mound, allowing one run and three hits while collecting 10 strikeouts.
content: Walker Buehler wore a blue sweatshirt in the dugout and the contented smile of someone who had successfully completed his job. But that’s a little like saying Michelangelo relaxed after he painted the room — not to put Walker’s latest opus on the same level as the artistic masterwork, but in the baseball sense, it was excellent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: UnitedHealth Ships Flu Kits to Medicare Recipients
description: Under MedAdvantage plans, the major insurer is sending packages including Tamiflu and coronavirus tests to those considered especially vulnerable to Covid and the flu.
content: With Covid-19 hospitalizations spiking again in many parts of the country, public health officials have expressed concerns about a perennial source of strain on the health care system: seasonal flu. As threats of a “twindemic” loom, health care workers have stressed the need for vaccination and other preventive measures to slow the spread of flu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: New Airport, Beleaguered Symbol of ‘Irreverent’ Berlin, Is Opening at Long Last
description: Nine years late and $4 billion over budget, the airport is already outdated. Repeated blunders dented the image of German efficiency, but the “poor but sexy” capital has long been a bit different.
content: BERLIN — Styled like a boarding card, Gregor Gysi’s invitation to the opening party of the “most modern airport in Europe” arrived in the mail. There would be 10,000 guests and a red carpet landing by Chancellor Angela Merkel on the runway. Mr. Gysi couldn’t wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: In South Korea, Draft Resisters Still Go to Prison. But Now It’s a Job.
description: A court ruled that conscientious objectors must be allowed to serve their country in other ways. The government says they’ll still have to do so behind prison walls.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Like thousands of other Jehovah’s Witnesses who refused to join the military because of their religious beliefs, Lee Seung-ki will serve time in a South Korean prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Murkowski, in a Turnabout, Says She Will Vote to Confirm Barrett
description: The iconoclastic Alaska Republican said she remained opposed to filling the Supreme Court seat so close to an election but could not hold that against a qualified nominee.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Lisa Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who has vocally opposed filling the vacant seat on the Supreme Court so close to an election, said on Saturday that she would nonetheless vote to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Maria Abi-Habib
title: As China Clamps Down, Activists Flee Hong Kong for Refuge in the West
description: China calls them “violent criminals.” Asylum seekers from Hong Kong are the latest catalyst for deteriorating relations between Beijing and Western countries.
content: HONG KONG — In Western democracies, they have been welcomed as refugees escaping Beijing’s tightening grip over Hong Kong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Grinspan
title: How to Steal an Election
description: Understanding past swindles can shed light on what we should worry about in 2020.
content: Around supper time on Election Day, 1880, the poll workers in Bolivar County, Miss., were getting hungry. Someone ran out for sardines and crackers. The officials noshed and counted votes until the “violent laxative” that had been added to the Republicans’ sardines started to take effect. Then they ran for the outhouses while the remaining Democrats counted a suspiciously large majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: ‘I voted for a guy named Trump,’ the president said after voting in person in Florida.
description: President Trump traveled to West Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday morning to cast his ballot in the 2020 election early and in person after spending months making unsubstantiated claims about voter fraud during an election in which polls have shown him to be trailing Joe Biden.
content: President Trump traveled to West Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday morning to cast his ballot in the 2020 election early and in person after spending months making unsubstantiated claims about voter fraud during an election in which polls have shown him to be trailing Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: While Her Father Rails Against ‘Idiot’ Scientists, Ivanka Trump Talks Ice Cream
description: The first daughter is trying to woo the white suburban female voters who have become her father’s demographic kryptonite.
content: FRANKLIN, Wis. — President Trump had just been on Fox and Friends, demanding that his attorney general “act” against his opponent before the election. He had, the day before, called Joseph R. Biden Jr. a “criminal,” Dr. Anthony S. Fauci a “disaster,” government scientists “idiots” and members of the news media “real garbage.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John F. Wasik
title: Once Meccas of Retail Therapy, Now Homes to Elder Americans
description: Former malls and abandoned shopping-center sites are in the midst of a repurposing — and one of those new uses is senior housing.
content: George and Pat Ritzinger moved five years ago to a community that few would initially consider a retirement mecca: a former shopping center site in Wayzata, Minn. They had spent the previous 15 years in a townhouse development in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, yet found the atmosphere chilly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 24, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 24, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about the #MeToo movement in Iran misidentified the position of Elnaaz Mohammadi at Abuse Watch, an education and advocacy group in Tehran. She is a member, not a co-founder. The article also imprecisely paraphrased her comments regarding the recipient of student complaints about Aydin Aghdashloo’s behavior. Ms. Mohammadi said she had received the complaints, not Abuse Watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: Biden, an Amtrak Evangelist, Could Be a Lifeline for a Rail Agency in Crisis
description: Amtrak has reduced service and is poised to cut thousands of jobs. Rail supporters argue that, win or lose, the Democratic presidential candidate could shift the debate over the agency’s future.
content: WASHINGTON — Joe Biden says he loves ice cream, aviators and Amtrak. But if elected president, his love for the rail agency may be put to the test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Golden
title: Will Cuba Tip Florida to Trump?
description: Sixty-two years after the revolution, America’s relations with its neighbor to the south loom large.
content: With Florida again looking pivotal in the presidential race, Donald Trump and Joe Biden have found themselves revisiting a decades-old question that could decide a crucial share of votes: What to do about Cuba?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Meacham
title: What the Tumultuous Year 1968 Can Teach Us About Today
description: The dangerous animosities of the past never went away, and have now re-emerged with new force.
content: Marshall Frady saw what was coming. It was the spring of 1968, and Frady, a writer for Newsweek, The New Yorker and Harper’s, was finishing a slim, evocative portrait of George C. Wallace, the once and future governor of Alabama who’d taken his segregationist platform national as a third-party candidate for president. “He has come virtually out of nowhere to intrude himself into the most vital political process of this country, at one of the most perilous moments in this country’s history,” Frady wrote in April of that tumultuous year. “For some time now — perhaps since the assassination of John F. Kennedy — there has been the sense of a certain dishevelment in the national life; in some subtle but fundamental way things seem to have become ungeared. It has been a season of anarchic happenings: a natural time for a bizarre happening like Wallace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nada Bakri
title: Preserving Food, Preserving Myself
description: This fall, the chores in my kitchen have become a way to stay connected to my Lebanese identity.
content: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — I forced the last mini cucumber in a jar and poured brine over it: My mother’s recipe calls for half a cup of coarse sea salt and half a cup of vinegar for every 12 cups of water, boiled and then cooled to room temperature. I have always relied on my cups and spoons to measure my ingredients. This time, though, I used the old floating raw egg trick to test the saltiness of the water, which I saw my grandmother use as a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: At the Halloween Play …
description: Join us for the drama of this Peter A. Collins spooky Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Happy Halloween week! Getting an early theme grid for a holiday is far preferable to that thing when Labor Day is Sept. 1, I think, and it’s nice to have a Sunday scary puzzle. It has been a year and a half since we’ve solved a big construction from Peter A. Collins, but he has been a steady contributor since 2006. Mr. Collins is the chairman of the math department at Huron High School in Ann Arbor, Mich., and hearing the phrase at 48-Across set this well-fleshed-out theme in motion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: The White Issue: Has Anna Wintour’s Diversity Push Come Too Late?
description: Vogue’s September issue celebrated Black culture and contributors. But some employees say the magazine’s powerful editor fostered a workplace that sidelined women of color.
content: Vogue’s September issue was different this year. Anna Wintour and her staff put it together when more than 15 million people were marching in Black Lives Matter protests nationwide and employees at Vogue’s parent company, Condé Nast, were publicly calling out what they viewed as racism in their own workplace. At 316 pages, the issue, titled “Hope,” featured a majority of Black artists, models and photographers, a first for the magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Trading Fear at Home for Misery on America’s Doorstep
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 24, 2020.
content: “I haven’t done anything, I haven’t stolen anything, and still I have to keep escaping. Why?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon put a gris-gris on our Sunday acrostic.
content: ACROSTIC — Of course we need an excerpt from a spooky story; after all, there’s a fraught election happening before we see Team Cox/Rathvon again (isn’t that something?). Today’s acrostic is taken from a very new novel called “Empire of Wild,” by Cherie Dimaline, about shape shifting in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: How the Designer of Milly Broke Free
description: With her husband, Michelle Smith built a successful clothing brand on the idea of demure femininity. Then she ripped up her life.
content: The wind was whipping around a makeshift outdoor SoulCycle studio at Manhattan’s Hudson Yards the other day, but the fashion designer Michelle Smith pulled off her “Legalize Equality” sweatshirt, baring toned limbs. She was hot. For the second time that day, she was front row and center in a spin class taught by her girlfriend, the platinum-haired star instructor Stacey Griffith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Illinois Police Officer Fired After Fatally Shooting Black Man
description: The officer was fired three days after he killed 19-year-old Marcellis Stinnette, the passenger in a car he had been approaching to investigate. The Justice Department has agreed to examine the case.
content: An Illinois police officer who shot and killed a 19-year-old Black man who was sitting in a car that was reversing toward the officer has been fired, according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: Everyone Is Gay on TikTok
description: Straight young men on the app are posting suggestive videos with their buddies. It’s not just about the views.
content: Connor Robinson, a 17-year-old British TikTok star with rosy cheeks and a budding six-pack, has built a large following by keeping his fans thirsty. Between the daily drip of shirtless dance routines and skits about his floppy hair, Mr. Robinson posts sexually suggestive curve balls that, he said, “break some barriers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Slamming Trump’s coronavirus response, Biden asks: ‘If this is a success, what’s a failure look like?’
description: With the presidential race hurtling into its final stretch, Joseph R. Biden Jr. sought on Friday to amplify the closing argument he delivered on the debate stage a night earlier, accusing President Trump of failing to stem the ballooning coronavirus crisis and vowing more aggressive federal action for the “dark winter ahead.”
content: With the presidential race hurtling into its final stretch, Joseph R. Biden Jr. sought on Friday to amplify the closing argument he delivered on the debate stage a night earlier, accusing President Trump of failing to stem the ballooning coronavirus crisis and vowing more aggressive federal action for the “dark winter ahead.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Troy Closson
title: Huge turnout in New York on first day of early voting.
description: At Madison Square Garden, Barclays Center and other sites, people arrived hours before polls opened. This is the first time that early voting has been allowed in New York in a presidential election.
content: New Yorkers flooded polling places on Saturday, the first day of early voting in the state, anxious to make sure their ballots are counted given the challenges of holding a contentious presidential election in the middle of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Murder Hornet Nest, First in U.S., Is Removed in Washington State
description: Officials vacuumed the nest in Blaine, Wash., on Saturday before the voracious Asian giant hornets could multiply and lay waste to bees.
content: Like detectives pouncing on a fugitive hide-out deep in the woods, officials in Washington State announced on Saturday that they had removed the first murder hornet nest in the United States, tucked in a tree hollow near the Canadian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: If A.O.C. Is So Heavily Favored, Why Has Her Race Drawn $30 Million?
description: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is expected to cruise to re-election, yet the race for her congressional seat is the second most expensive House campaign in the nation.
content: All the money in the world is not likely to influence the outcome of Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s re-election bid in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Raphael Minder
title: Venezuela Opposition Figure, Long Confined, Flees to Spain
description: Leopoldo López had spent the past six years in jail, house arrest and diplomatic asylum. He fled on Saturday, joining his family in Spain.
content: The Venezuelan opposition leader Leopoldo López fled the country Saturday after spending the past six years in jail, house arrest and diplomatic asylum, his political party said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: ‘Ooh … Impressive!’
description: Sink your teeth into this Byron Walden Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We have another heavy hitter today, Byron Walden, with his 64th New York Times Saturday grid. I flopped around for ages before I was able to make a single connection more meaningful than TRON and SOUCI in the southeast corner, and I also had to undo many missteps, so this was a hard-fought victory. The nice thing about this sort of solve is the ample time you get to ponder the gems and the oddities, of which there are many (including 12 debuts!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Ronen Bergman
title: Israel Sees Warming Ties With Sudan as Symbolic Progress in Hostile Region
description: Sudan holds historic significance for Israeli leaders because it was the scene of a landmark resolution by Arab states that vowed to shun Israel. The two countries have had a rocky, colorful track record.
content: JERUSALEM — For Israel, the move toward normalization of ties with Sudan does not represent the same kind of landmark strategic achievement as the peace treaties decades ago with Egypt and Jordan, once-bitter Arab enemies on its borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: How The Epoch Times Created a Giant Influence Machine
description: Since 2016, the Falun Gong-backed newspaper has used aggressive Facebook tactics and right-wing misinformation to create an anti-China, pro-Trump media empire.
content: For years, The Epoch Times was a small, low-budget newspaper with an anti-China slant that was handed out free on New York street corners. But in 2016 and 2017, the paper made two changes that transformed it into one of the country’s most powerful digital publishers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Tess Felder
title: President Andrzej Duda of Poland Tests Positive for Coronavirus
description: A spokesman said the head of state was feeling well despite a positive test result. A second political leader is also in isolation after he came in contact with an infected person.
content: BRUSSELS — President Andrzej Duda of Poland has tested positive for Covid-19 and will go into quarantine, his spokesman said on Saturday, adding to the list of global leaders who have been infected as coronavirus cases rise unabated in several world hot spots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: She Used to Clean City Hall. Now, She Runs It.
description: In Russia, elections are typically theatrical affairs with the winner and loser preordained. Sometimes, though, they go off script.
content: POVALIKHINO, Russia — With election day looming, Nikolai Loktev was in a panic: The mayor of a tiny village of log houses, wood-burning stoves and rutted dirt roads 300 miles east of Moscow, he was running for re-election unopposed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: White House Releases New Plan for Seismic Tests in Arctic Refuge
description: The survey would bring heavy trucks looking for signs of oil reserves into one of the most remote and pristine parts of the United States.
content: The Trump administration has relaunched long-delayed plans to conduct a seismic survey in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska as a prelude to drilling for oil there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Early Virus Scares Kept the M.L.B. Season on Track
description: With the season’s finish line in sight, M.L.B.’s medical director said the outbreaks among the Cardinals and the Marlins this summer were a “wake-up call” that ultimately helped the sport.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — It is a memorable image of nearly every World Series opener: The members of each team standing shoulder to shoulder along the baselines, the players in the lineup announced one by one, the managers shaking hands over home plate. A celebrity belts out the national anthem while dozens of people clutch the edges of a giant American flag stretched across the outfield.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Perfect Chocolate Chip Cookies
description: Make a batch this weekend.
content: This weekend make Ravneet Gill’s perfect chocolate chip cookies, adapted by Charlotte Druckman (above), Nicole Taylor’s berry-jam fried chicken or Alexa Weibel’s quick chicken and dumplings. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: New Visa Limits Would Be a Self-Inflicted Wound for the U.S.
description: The Trump administration wants to make it harder for foreign students, exchange visitors and journalists.
content: From day one, a hallmark of the Trump administration has been its relentless assault on immigration, legal and illegal alike. President Trump’s obsession with building a wall on the southern border symbolizes that obsession and all its cruelty and uselessness. Far more insidious, though, is the invisible wall of restrictive policies, procedural changes or extreme vetting directives, lacking any justification beyond a vague and unsubstantiated reference to national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Amy Coney Barrett’s Rise Is a Threat to Families Like Mine
description: Many of us thought gays and lesbians had won the marriage battle. Maybe not.
content: It’s not often that I get gay married. The week I did it a second time was the same week we heard about the anti-gay proclivities of the Supreme Court nominee, Amy Coney Barrett, and some current justices called into question the very ruling that allowed me to get married in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Joe Biden Had Close Ties With Police Leaders. Will They Help Him Now?
description: His proposed solution to addressing both urgent calls for police reform and animosity from law enforcement toward Democrats is one he’s long relied on: He’ll just get everyone in the same room.
content: Bill Johnson knew, before he reached out to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign last spring, that things had changed between the former vice president and the nation’s police unions. A once-close alliance had frayed amid clashes over police brutality and racism in the justice system. Still, Mr. Johnson, the executive director of the National Association of Police Organizations, invited Mr. Biden to address the group as it weighed its 2020 endorsement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Pressure Your Landlord to Keep Your Building Safe
description: Landlords are required to provide a minimum level of security. Anything beyond that may require action from the tenants.
content: Q: I live in a luxury rental building in Brooklyn. We have a doorman, but not 24-hour security. I recently noticed that the door to the bike room was busted. After getting evasive responses from the concierge and building management, I learned from another tenant that the front door had been broken into twice in separate attempts to burglarize the bike room. The building needs security, and other tenants agree. How can we pressure management to keep us safe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Trump’s Biggest Economic Legacy Isn’t About the Numbers
description: The president has shifted the way both parties talk about trade, immigration and deficits — and despite dismal economic news, many voters still reward him for it.
content: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — To understand how much President Trump has altered the conversation around the economy, just listen to Bruce Haines, who spent decades as an executive at U.S. Steel before becoming a managing partner of the elegant Historic Hotel Bethlehem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Antonio Brown Plans to Visit Buccaneers as His Suspension Nears Its End
description: Brown, who has not played since Week 2 last season, still faces an N.F.L. investigation into accusations that he sexually assaulted his former trainer in 2017 and 2018.
content: Antonio Brown, the former All-Pro wide receiver who is finishing an eight-game suspension after pleading no contest to burglary and battery charges and receiving two years’ probation, will visit the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, his first step toward a return to the N.F.L.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Edith O’Hara, a Fixture of Off Off Broadway, Dies at 103
description: The theater she founded, the 13th Street Repertory Company, has been an eclectic presence on the New York scene for almost half a century.
content: Edith O’Hara, who started the 13th Street Repertory Company in Greenwich Village in 1972 and made it a quirky mainstay of New York’s Off Off Broadway scene, keeping it going through the decades while countless other companies fell by the wayside, died on Oct. 16 at her home, an apartment above the theater. She was 103.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval, Troy Closson and Nate Schweber
title: Lines Stretch for Blocks as New Yorkers Turn Out for Early Voting
description: Voters in New York City waited hours to cast ballots on Saturday, the first time that early voting has been allowed in the state in a presidential election.
content: Tens of thousands of New Yorkers flooded polling places and waited hours in long lines on Saturday, the first day of early voting, with many saying that they turned out because of concerns that their ballots might not be counted if they tried to vote by mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Sofía Villamil
title: Indigenous Colombians, Facing New Wave of Brutality, Demand Government Action
description: “If we don’t stand before the world and say, ‘This is happening,’ we will be exterminated,” a protest leader said. After a long civil war, a new type of violence is sweeping Indigenous communities.
content: Protesters descended by the thousands on Colombia’s capital, Bogotá, this week, horrified by a brutal wave of violence sweeping the country, one so intense that mass killings have taken place every other day on average.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Wealthy Millennial Women Tend to Defer to Husbands on Investing
description: Even the most educated and high-achieving women do not participate equally with their husbands in long-term financial decision making, according to a study.
content: When Representative Katie Porter ended her troubled marriage, leaving was tough, but one thing made it easier: For years, she had handled the family’s investments and savings plans, and she was confident that she and her children would be OK.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Austin Barnes Give the Dodgers an Unlikely Lift at the Plate
description: Barnes, a backup catcher, has been a mainstay in the World Series for the Dodgers because of his defense, but he delivered a home run and a timely bunt in Game 3.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — Pity the backup catcher, so often the forgotten man in late October. He owes his roster spot to his competence at a peculiar position, often summoned only in case of an injury to the starter. That tends to keep him tied to the bench, rarely used as a pinch-hitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: New York City billboards featuring Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner draw a threatening letter.
description: A lawyer for Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner threatened Friday to take legal action against the Lincoln Project, a super PAC made up of anti-Trump conservatives, unless the group removes a pair of large billboards from Times Square in Manhattan.
content: A lawyer for Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner threatened Friday to take legal action against the Lincoln Project, a super PAC made up of anti-Trump conservatives, unless the group removes a pair of large billboards from Times Square in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Forging Through ‘the Chaos of Life’ Together
description: In their two decades of marriage, Mary Sebonia Rhodes has become “more open, patient and compassionate.” Matt Rhodes learned resiliency.
content: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: R.I.P., G.O.P.
description: The Party of Lincoln had a good run. Then came Mr. Trump.
content: Of all the things President Trump has destroyed, the Republican Party is among the most dismaying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Najim Rahim
title: Deadly Explosion Hits Kabul Tutoring Center
description: At least 24 people were killed and 57 wounded in latest attack, which happened as peace talks are at an impasse and as violence rises across Afghanistan.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — A deadly explosion struck a tutoring center in Kabul on Saturday, puncturing a relatively peaceful period in the Afghan capital even as violence has spiraled upward in the countryside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Dobbins
title: Arrest Leads to Tragedy in the Rio Grande Valley
description: Jorge Gonzalez Zuniga’s death after a brutal arrest prompted protests that are rare in a region where undocumented immigrants often prefer to stay silent.
content: EDINBURG, Texas — Officer Coltynn Williams was the first person at the Hidalgo County Jail to actually see Jorge Gonzalez Zuniga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Navy Plane Crashes in Alabama, Killing Crew of 2
description: The plane crashed next to a house. No civilians on the ground were injured, the authorities said.
content: A Navy plane crashed in a residential area in Southern Alabama on Friday afternoon, killing its two crew members, the Navy said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shola Lawal
title: As Lawlessness Roils Nigeria, Police Chief Vows to Take Back Streets
description: As protests against police brutality have subsided after a violent crackdown, they have been followed by a wave of looting and vandalism that the police have vowed to end.
content: LAGOS — Nigeria’s police chief on Saturday ordered the mobilization of all police resources to reclaim public space after more than two weeks of peaceful protests over police brutality gave way to widespread vandalism and looting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: King Kong Trump, Losing His Grip
description: A steaming mad president is running out of steam.
content: WASHINGTON — During the Barack Obama comet streak in 2008, a lot of Americans were electrified by the idea of leaping into modernity with a brainy, young, Black cool cat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Astead W. Herndon
title: Trump’s Rallies, Red-State Democrats: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: At the debate, President Trump and Joe Biden were actually able to debate. Offstage, both candidates are carrying on distinctly different campaign styles that suit them best.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Thomas Kaplan and Annie Karni
title: At Dueling Rallies, Campaigns Present Starkly Different Visions on Virus
description: Candidates made their cases as hundreds of thousands of people jammed long lines to vote in New York, Florida and elsewhere.
content: A day after the nation hit a new high for coronavirus cases, President Trump returned to the campaign trail for a series of rallies and again sought to minimize the surging pandemic, mocking his rival, Joseph R. Biden Jr., for following the social distancing recommendations of public health officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Jerry Jeff Walker, Who Wrote and Sang ‘Mr. Bojangles,’ Dies at 78
description: He never had a Top 40 pop hit. But his best-known composition became a standard, and he became a mainstay of the outlaw country movement.
content: Jerry Jeff Walker, the singer-songwriter who wrote the much-recorded standard “Mr. Bojangles” and later became a mainstay of the Texas outlaw movement that catapulted Willie Nelson and Waylon Jennings to fame, died on Friday at a hospital in Austin, Texas. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger, Kevin Quealy, Chad Batka, Celeste Sloman and Rumsey Taylor
title: These Americans Tried to Listen to One Another. A Year Later, Here’s How They’re Voting.
description: A year ago, 526 voters met in Texas to talk politics. We caught up with them ahead of the election.
content: A year ago, 526 voters met in Texas to talk politics. We caught up with them ahead of the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Murder Hornet Nest Destroyed in Washington State
description: Officials said they had removed an Asian giant hornet’s nest discovered in a tree near Blaine, Wash., before the insects could multiply and lay waste to bee colonies. The nest was the first to be found in the United States.
content: Officials said they had removed an Asian giant hornet’s nest discovered in a tree near Blaine, Wash., before the insects could multiply and lay waste to bee colonies. The nest was the first to be found in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wrangling Over Herd Immunity and Masks as Covid Cases Keep Rising
description: Readers are skeptical of herd immunity as a strategy and view mask-wearing as a limit on one’s freedom in order to save lives.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
